explanation:
- OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET: This macro expands inline in the target function and could itself contain a for statement or other loop constructs. To determine MISRA compliance you must inspect the macro expansion to see any for loops, their loop counters, and whether the three clauses meet the rule (no persistent side effects, only loop-counter modifications, only one loop counter, etc.).

- OS_impl_count_sem_table: This object is an argument to OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET. The macro expansion may iterate over this table or index into it; its type/definition is needed to understand how the macro uses indices or loop counters and whether any objects used as counters are modified elsewhere.

- OS_object_token_t: The function dereferences *token and passes it into OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET. The token's definition is required to see what fields are used by the macro/callee (e.g. an embedded id), and whether those fields could be or are treated as loop counters or be modified (which would affect clauses 1–4 of the MISRA rule).

- OS_impl_countsem_internal_record_t: The type of impl is needed to know the type of impl->id and any other members that OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET or subsequent calls might access. If the macro or any called function modifies members of this struct that are also used as loop counters, that would be relevant under the rule.

- OS_ObjectIndexFromToken: The static call graph indicates this function is invoked (likely via the OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET expansion). Its implementation must be examined because any for loops inside it contribute to the behaviour of calls made from the target function (MISRA states the behaviour of called functions is part of the loop body). You must verify any for loops in that function are well-formed per the listed clauses.

- sem_post: Although normally a library call, sem_post could be implemented as a macro or inline wrapper containing loops or side-effecting expressions. Its declaration/definition is needed to be sure calling it (and passing &impl->id) does not introduce for-loops or modify objects that would act as loop counters in any enclosing for loop.

Note: The target function has no explicit for loop itself, so the only way MISRA requirement for 'for' statements could be implicated is if a macro expansion or any called function (listed above) contains a for statement. The symbols above are precisely those needed to inspect macro expansions and callees for such for loops and to check the MISRA clauses (loop-counter initialization, allowed side effects, single counter, and no modification in the body).
